segment.source: Overview of rotation
segment.target: Overview of rotation

segment.source: Rotation is the touch-optimized technique used by UWP apps to enable users to turn an object in a circular direction (clockwise or counter-clockwise).
segment.target: Rotation is the touch-optimized technique used by UWP apps to enable users to turn an object in a circular direction (clockwise or counter-clockwise).

segment.source: Depending on the input device, the rotation interaction is performed using:
segment.target: Depending on the input device, the rotation interaction is performed using:

segment.source: A mouse or active pen/stylus to move the rotation gripper of a selected object.
segment.target: A mouse or active pen/stylus to move the rotation gripper of a selected object.

segment.source: Touch or passive pen/stylus to turn the object in the desired direction using the rotate gesture.
segment.target: Touch or passive pen/stylus to turn the object in the desired direction using the rotate gesture.

segment.source: Intuitively, and in most cases, the rotation point is one of the two touch points unless the user can specify a rotation point unrelated to the contact points (for example, in a drawing or layout application).
segment.target: Intuitively, and in most cases, the rotation point is one of the two touch points unless the user can specify a rotation point unrelated to the contact points (for example, in a drawing or layout application).

segment.source: Windows 8 supports three types of rotation: free, constrained, and combined.
segment.target: Windows 8 supports three types of rotation: free, constrained, and combined.

segment.source: Type
segment.target: Type

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: Free rotation
segment.target: Free rotation

segment.source: Free rotation enables a user to rotate content freely anywhere in a 360 degree arc.
segment.target: Free rotation enables a user to rotate content freely anywhere in a 360 degree arc.

segment.source: When the user releases the object, the object remains in the chosen position.
segment.target: When the user releases the object, the object remains in the chosen position.

segment.source: Free rotation is useful for drawing and layout applications such as Microsoft PowerPoint, Word, Visio, and Paint; and Adobe Photoshop, Illustrator, and Flash.
segment.target: Free rotation is useful for drawing and layout applications such as Microsoft PowerPoint, Word, Visio, and Paint; and Adobe Photoshop, Illustrator, and Flash.

segment.source: Constrained rotation
segment.target: Constrained rotation

segment.source: Constrained rotation supports free rotation during the manipulation but enforces snap points at 90 degree increments (0, 90, 180, and 270) upon release.
segment.target: Constrained rotation supports free rotation during the manipulation but enforces snap points at 90 degree increments (0, 90, 180, and 270) upon release.

segment.source: When the user releases the object, the object automatically rotates to the nearest snap point.
segment.target: When the user releases the object, the object automatically rotates to the nearest snap point.

segment.source: Constrained rotation is the most common method of rotation, and it functions in a similar way to scrolling content.
segment.target: Constrained rotation is the most common method of rotation, and it functions in a similar way to scrolling content.

segment.source: Snap points let a user be imprecise and still achieve their goal.
segment.target: Snap points let a user be imprecise and still achieve their goal.

segment.source: Constrained rotation is useful for applications such as web browsers and photo albums.
segment.target: Constrained rotation is useful for applications such as web browsers and photo albums.

segment.source: Combined rotation
segment.target: Combined rotation

segment.source: Combined rotation supports free rotation with zones (similar to rails in Guidelines for panning) at each of the 90 degree snap points enforced by constrained rotation.
segment.target: Combined rotation supports free rotation with zones (similar to rails in Guidelines for panning) at each of the 90 degree snap points enforced by constrained rotation.

segment.source: If the user releases the object outside of one of 90 degree zones, the object remains in that position; otherwise, the object automatically rotates to a snap point.
segment.target: If the user releases the object outside of one of 90 degree zones, the object remains in that position; otherwise, the object automatically rotates to a snap point.

segment.source: Note A user interface rail is a feature in which an area around a target constrains movement towards some specific value or location to influence its selection.
segment.target: Note A user interface rail is a feature in which an area around a target constrains movement towards some specific value or location to influence its selection.
